Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Finite Amplitude Gravity Wave Trains in the Upper Mesosphere - Lower Thermosphere Duct System: Build Up and Leakage of Energy from Local and Distant Sources
Award.AbstractNarration: Earth's mesosphere and lower thermosphere (MLT) contain thermal and wind structures that can support a large population of ducted waves that are confined to localized regions where conditions support their existence and propagation. Often, waves can travel simultaneously in multiple ducts. Distinctive aspects of these waves are that they may grow to large amplitudes, travel large distances horizontally and induce changes far from their sources. Waves ducted in two ducts simultaneously may carry much greater energy over larger distances than waves confined to a single duct. There is a growing body of evidence that large-amplitude ducted waves are associated with frequent occurrences of extensive changes in the MLT. Ducted waves may affect broader regions of the atmosphere than non-ducted waves since the former may transfer energy horizontally over long distances prior to dissipation. Even weak or partial ducting may cause a significant redistribution of wave energy. Ducted waves provide a mechanism for prolific wave sources such as in low-latitude convective zones. The processes by which waves may attain large amplitudes, transfer energy from distant sources and produce effects in the MLT where the waves become untrapped need to be better understood and better characterized to help improve our understanding of the wave control of the MLT. Such a characterization would be the basis for improved parameterization schemes of wave drag for general circulation models. This investigation is a theoretical study supported by data analysis to address outstanding questions concerning the role of ducted waves in the MLT. The specific objectives are to assess the buildup of wave energy in MLT ducts and the propagation and leakage of energy from ducts under realistic MLT conditions. The study will use theory, numerical modeling, and comparisons to observations of ducted waves from an extensive data base of ducted quasi-monochromatic wave events. Data will be obtained from airglow imagers, lidar and radar from diverse locations (Andes Lidar Observatory, Maui, Adelaide, and Alice Springs) and from the SABER instrument on the TIMED satellite. The research focuses on a largely unexplored mechanism for effecting the global redistribution of wave energy in the mesospheric and lower-thermospheric ducting system. The work will establish that ducts populated by prolific wave sources in the lower atmosphere are of considerable geophysical importance far from the source regions. The results will lead to the development of modeling capabilities for investigating ducting as a means of wave growth and the redistribution of wave energy between regions of the atmosphere, both vertically and horizontally. It will support coordinated multi-instrument investigations at existing sites, and provide a continuing research opportunity for a female scientist and a graduate student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Earth's atmosphere supports a broad spectrum of buoyant and compressional wave motions that can be generated by meteorological processes. Of special interest are gravity waves (also known as buoyancy waves) that have periods of several-to-tens of minutes and wavelengths of tens-to-hundreds of kilometers. Gravity waves are important for their roles in carrying momentum and energy from the lower atmosphere into the upper atmosphere. Thus, gravity waves enable weather in the troposphere to influence "weather" in the upper atmosphere and local space environment (e.g., the thermosphere and ionosphere). This is an example of a coupling process between separated atmospheric regions, and understanding the generation, propagation, and effects of gravity waves is necessary to model and predict the structure of the upper-atmosphere. 

Although gravity waves are often observed to propagate upward to altitudes exceeding 100 km, variations in winds and temperatures can also cause reflections, leading to trapping of waves over narrow regions of altitudes. Waves that become trapped are able to propagate longer horizontal distances, but are less able to create strong effects locally. This project emphasized the effects of the atmospheric structure in controlling the upward and horizontal propagation of waves throughout the atmosphere and, thus, their effects in varied atmospheric structure. The methodology primarily used by our group was numerical modeling. The team also interfaced with experimentalists, and their students, to conduct modeling case studies defined by real data.

The postdoctoral research associate and principal investigators worked closely to develop model simulations to study the propagation of waves through complex atmospheres, and interactions between waves of different scales. We investigated different physical assumptions that are made within models; e.g., to understand what happens when small-scale wave encounters winds that only mimic the structure of a medium-scale wave, as compared to when they encounter realistic, propagating medium-scale waves. Results find that the time-dependent evolutions of medium-scale waves strongly determines the evolutions of the small scale waves, and the altitudes over which they impact the atmosphere. This implies that the mutual, transient evolutions of both are important for describing their dynamics. Further, we investigated how waves are dispersed and dissipated in realistic atmospheres, and how this affected their amplitudes and characteristics at different altitudes over time. Results provided new guidance for interpreting observations of broad spectra of waves, the effects of which may be distributed over very large volumes in the atmosphere. 

As broader impacts, the project provided important career development opportunities for the postdoctoral researcher, and enabled productive collaborations with graduate students and with scientists spanning multiple institutions. Computational models were also further-enhanced as part of this project, building capabilities that provide direct benefits to other studies. The results of these investigations were published in several papers and presented at workshops and conferences.
